Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Gradient-Enabled Ferroic Phenomena: Tunable Metastable States, Roto-Flexo, and Transport Properties
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: The functional properties of ferroelectrics and ferroelastics, materials with built-in polarization and elastic distortion states in their crystal structure, respectively, are typically reliant on their response under uniform spatial elastic and electric fields, e.g., switching, piezoelectric, and electro-optic responses. There is also a rich range of ferroic phenomena arising under gradient fields, which receive much less attention. This project is based on two new discoveries/ideas initiated by the US/Ukraine team: New highly tunable metastable states and roto-flexo phenomena. Strong gradient fields created at and in the proximity of domain walls can result in local phase transitions that lead to new bulk polar phases not normally expected in classic textbook ferroelectrics, and even in non-polar ferroelastics. In all oxide interfaces with oxygen octahedral tilts, the creation of a polarization (up to 1-10 microC/cm2) is predicted through a rotostriction-flexoelectric product effect that can significantly impact the interface charge transport. Using optical second harmonic generation microscopy, Raman microscopy, scanning probe microscopy, nanoscale X-ray diffraction imaging, z-contrast scanning transmission electron microscopy, analytical theory, phase-field modeling, and first principles theory, this collaborative team explores these new phenomena. Broadly speaking, the US team (Pennsylvania State University, Oak Ridge National Labs, Argonne National Labs) conducts experimental research and performs phase-field simulations, and the Ukrainian team (National Academy of Sciences, Ukraine) focuses on developing the theoretical framework.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: This project can potentially lead to new highly tunable, large piezoelectric response lead-free materials useful for precision motion and sensors. Gradient couplings at interfaces can lead to two-dimensional electron gas systems of great current interest for next generation high-speed transistors. This project also develops cutting-edge quantitative microscopy tools and advances theoretical modeling by simulating flexoelectric and other gradient effects. The NSF award provides funds to energize and sustain an international research team, which started in 2007. It funds undergraduate and graduate students to work and collaborate in a global context, supports extended visits across the Atlantic by PIs and students, furthers interactions between a university (Penn State), national labs (Oak Ridge and Argonne) and international collaborators (NAS-Ukraine), supports outreach activities through K-12, and provides research opportunities for women and underrepresented groups.

This project is supported by the Electronic and Photonic Materials program and Office of Special Programs, Division of Materials Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The proposal originally funded in 2012 explored new phenomena arising from gradient effects namely, a variation of properties on the atomic and nanometer scale, in ferroelectrics, materials with a built-in electrical polarization.  Ferroelectrics can possess very strong gradients; For example, strain gradients of ~2-5% per nm, polarizations of 1-50 μC/cm2, polarization gradients of 1-50 x107 C/m3, magnetization of ~0.5MA/m, magnetization gradients of ~5x107 MA/m3, and local electric fields up to several MV/cm can arise, enabling new phenomena to arise. Through an NSF-CREATIV grant extension in 2015, this project (with the same grant number) was extended by two years (2015-2017, with one year of no-cost extension) under the title: “Exploring Hidden symmetries of distortions in materials, and the consequent property predictions.”  We recently developed a new symmetry concept called distortion-reversal symmetry.   We developed the theory of this symmetry operation, as well as explored the property consequences, particular with regards to domains and domain walls in ferroelectrics.  This has led to the development of a new computational tool to predict minimum energy pathways in physical sciences.  The proposal led to over 40 refereed publications. Some of the work is highlighted below.

(1)  Discovery of emergent phases with large property enhancements: The design of new or enhanced functionality in materials is traditionally viewed as requiring the discovery of new chemical compositions through synthesis. Large property enhancements may however also be hidden within already well-known materials, when their structural symmetry is deviated from equilibrium through a small local strain or field. In classic ferroelectrics BaTiO3 and KNbO3, crystals known for over half a century, we discovered new phases with piezoelectric and nonlinear optical properties that are up to 400-500% higher than the conventional phases (Lummen, Nature Comm. 2014, Advanced Materials, 2017).  These phases are stabilized by broken crystal symmetry with very small strains. This discovery reveals a potential new route to local engineering of significant property enhancements and conductivity through symmetry lowering in ferroelectric crystals.

(2)   Exotic Polar Structures:  Given the large distortions in ferroelectrics, it was usually believed that polarization directions are strictly constrained by crystallographic directions (Ising directions) and that they do not easily deviate (so called Bloch and Neel polarization components). The PIs were the first to predict that such Bloch and Neel deviations were indeed possible (Phys. Rev Rapid communications, 2009).  In this project, the developed a full theory of these components and found their origin to arise from flexoelectric effects (Gu, Phys. Rev B, 2014 and others). Further, we proposed making such components very large using atomic scale multilayers of different ferroelectrics.  Using this strategy, we predicted and collaboratively demonstrated exotic polar orders, such as polar vortices (Nature, 2016, Nature Materials, 2017) and polar bubbles (Acta Materialia, 2018).

(3)  Discovery of new antisymmetry: Physical systems evolve from one state to another along paths of least energy barrier. We recently introduced a new antisymmetry called the distortion reversal symmetry (Nature Comm. 2015; Phys. Rev. B, 2018), and “distortion symmetry groups” as a complete description of the symmetry of a path has been introduced. We have listed all these symmetry groups which can be found here (http://sites.psu.edu/gopalan/research/symmetry/). The method, which we name the distortion symmetry method, is shown to lead to the discovery of previously hidden pathways for the case studies of bulk ferroelectric switching and domain wall motion in proper and improper ferroelectrics, as well as in multiferroic switching. The distortion symmetry method is applicable to a wide variety of physical phenomena ranging from structural, electronic and magnetic distortions, diffusion, and phase transitions in materials. We recently encoded this symmetry into public computational codes such as Quantum Espresso.  We have developed a tool called DiSPy which can be found at the following link: https://github.com/munrojm/DiSPy

Broader Impact:  The project led to the training and graduation of 7 graduate students, 2 postdocs and 10 undergraduates (including 3 women and 4 Hispanic students).  The work of four of these undergraduates (Jesus, Kingsland, Huang, Liu) led to refereed publications.  The PIs performed outreach every year of the project, including to elementary, middle and high scools, as well as summer science camps.  The broader impact of the discovery of a new symmetry in Nature, and its utility in discovering minimum energy paths in physical processes using the new tool DiSpy (Distortion Symmetry in Python) we have developed and publicly released could be significant.
